questions.text: In a patient with Wilson's disease which of the following is decreased in urine?
questions.solution:
Urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are decreased in patients with Wilson disease.

Amino acids in urine exist either in conjugated form (most) or in free form. In Wilson's disease the amount of conjugated amino acids far exceeds the amount of free amino acids. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine. Hence low amounts is seen in Wilson's disease.

Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder caused by mutation of the ATP7B gene located on chromosome 13. The ATP7B gene, encodes a transmembrane copper-transporting ATPase, expressed on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

Deficiency in the ATP7B protein causes a decrease in copper excretion into the bile, impairs its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and inhibits ceruloplasmin secretion into the blood, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of copper in the liver, brain, and eye.

questions.text: Brown sequard syndrome is characterized by _____

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.(fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally. )

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: NADPH is used in ______.
questions.solution:
NADPH is the source of reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis.

 This NADPH is derived from 3 sources:

  • HMP shunt pathway (main source)
  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except:
questions.solution:
Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

Pectineal ligament, inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament are derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae.

Uvula vesicae is an elevation in the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder, behind the internal urethral orifice. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: Acid Citrate Dextrose (ACD), used to store blood, preserves the RBCs for a period of 21 days. The storage period when adding phosphate alone and when adding adenine and phosphate together to ACD would respectively be?
questions.solution:
The storage period when adding phosphate alone to ACD would be 21 days and when adding adenine and phosphate together would be 35 days.

When adding phosphate to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose (CPD) is formed – It has a storage period of 21 days. There is no change in the shelf life as phosphate only increases the 2,3 DPG levels of the stored blood.

When adding both phosphate and adenine to ACD, Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-1) is formed. It has a storage period of 35 days. It increases the shelf life by improving ATP synthesis of RBCs.

Using additive solutions containing saline, adenine, and glucose, with or without mannitol (SAGM) decreases RBC hemolysis, thus increasing the storage period to 42 days.

questions.text: The movements at the ____________ joint permit a person to look to the right and left.
questions.solution:
The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.

The atlanto-axial joints include 3 synovial joints:

  • Median atlanto-axial joint- The central pivot joint between the dens of the axis and a ring formed by the anterior arch and transverse atlantal ligament 
  • Lateral atlanto-axial joints- Plain synovial joints between lateral masses of atlas and upper facets of the body of axis

Movements at the atlanto-axial joint almost exclusively is rotation around the axis, which help side-to-side rotation of the head. The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.solution:
Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

Fibers of medial lemniscus ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord to the medulla, where they synapse in the gracilus and cuneate nuclei.

The second-order neurons from these nuclei cross the midline and ascend in the medial lemniscus to end in the contralateral ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus and related specific sensory relay nuclei of the thalamus.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except _____

choices.text: It's diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conal artery is it's first branch

questions.solution:
The right coronary artery does not give rise to the circumflex coronary artery.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and continues in the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart.

The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery.

The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery.

The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery and is the exclusive supplier to the right bundle branch.

questions.text: α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme ________.
questions.solution:
α1-antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of the enzyme neutrophil elastase.

  • Lysosomal enzymes, if unchecked, can potentiate further inflammation by damaging tissues.
  • These harmful proteases, however, are normally controlled by a system of antiproteases in the serum and tissue fluids.
  • α1-antitrypsin is the prototype member of the serine protease inhibitor (serpin) superfamily of proteins.

Clinical correlate:

  • Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency (α1-ATD) is caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene located in the long arm of chromosome 14.
  • This genetic defect alters the configuration of the α1-antitrypsin molecule and prevents its release from hepatocytes.
  • As a result, serum levels of α1-antitrypsin are decreased, leading to low alveolar concentrations, where the α1-antitrypsin molecule normally would provide protection against proteases such neutrophil elastase.
  • The resulting protease excess in alveoli destroys alveolar walls and causes emphysema.

This is a NEET pattern MCQ.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber?
questions.solution:
Gum is the best answer among the given options. Even though all of the given options are dietary fibers, the consumption of gums through diet is very low and hence, it is the best answer.

Dietary fibers consist of both soluble and insoluble forms and include lignin, pectin, inulin, cellulose, hemicellulose, etc.

Advantages of fibers:

  • Forms bulk of the stool and reduces stool transit time
  • Reduces incidence of carcinoma colon, DM, CAD, diverticulitis

questions.text: Testosterone production is mainly contributed by ______
questions.solution:
Testosterone production is mainly contributed by Leydig cells.

Testosterone is synthesized from cholesterol in the Leydig cells and also from androstenedione secreted by the adrenal cortex.

The diagnosis of testosterone deficiency should be made only on the basis of clinical signs and symptoms consistent with androgen deficiency, and consistently subnormal serum testosterone concentrations at 8 to 10 AM on three occasions. 

Testosterone has been used to treat primary or secondary hypogonadism in adult men.

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Foot drop is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between great and second toes.

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

Th image given below shows the course of common peroneal nerve.

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:

choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

From the picture given below, (FRC = ERV + RV).

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath.

Lung volumes, capacities, and their combinations are being tested year after year in the various competitive exams.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to _________

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.solution:
Golgi tendon organ sense changes in muscle tension.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension in a contracted muscle is significantly elevated, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphalocele?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Omphalocele is protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring. It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity, which results in non-closure of the umbilical ring. .

An omphalocele may contain stomach, liver, and intestines. And these contents are enclosed in a sac.

Omphalocele is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

Note: In gastroschisis, there is an absence of a membranous sac and is paraumbilical.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution:
Levator veli palatini is not derived from first pharyngeal arch. 

All soft palate muscles including levator veli palatini are derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch and are supplied by vagal plexus.

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

  • Tensor tympani

  • Anterior 2⁄3 of tongue.

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Vitamin A is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate).

Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These are present, lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse).

questions.solution:
Postganglionic sympathetic (type C) has the least conduction velocity among the given options.

questions.text: Cholecysto-vena caval line separates which of the following?

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.solution:
Cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) separates right and left lobe of the liver.

Cantlie line is an imaginary line that that divides the liver into 2 planes. It extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava (IVC) and contains the middle hepatic vein.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

questions.text: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with the deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). 

Early symptoms of thiamine deficiency include peripheral neuropathy, irritability, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and proprioception. As the disease progresses, increased intracranial pressure, meningismus, and coma develop.

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome:
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial genome is maternally inherited.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperms contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.

Pedigree shows mitochondrial inheritance.

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulins are not synthesized by the liver. They are produced by plasma cells.

Plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: Common precursor amino acid for urea, creatine and nitric oxide is____.
questions.solution:
Arginine is the common precursor for urea, creatine and nitric oxide.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: In Menke’s disease, which of the following enzymes would be affected?
questions.solution:
Menke’s disease is due to defective lysyl oxidase.

It is an X‐linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in ATP7A, which encodes for a copper-transporting ATPase‐α polypeptide.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder.

It is caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

The primary defect is abnormal chondrocyte proliferation at the growth plate that causes development of short and thick bones.

Clinical features:

  • Short limbs
  • Normal trunk
  • Large head
  • Saddle nose
  • Exaggerated lumbar lordosis
  • Severe spinal deformity may lead to cord compression

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following  causes increased glutamine in blood?
questions.solution:
Deficiency ornithine transcarbamoylase causes increased glutamine in blood

Ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline in the urea cycle. Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate is then shunted to pyrimidine biosynthesis, resulting in high ammonia and orotic acid levels in the blood. This condition is thus called hyperammonemia type 2.

As a compensatory mechanism, ammonia is then combined with glutamate to form glutamine (by the enzyme glutamine synthetase). The levels of glutamine are elevated in the blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine, probably as a result of this dysregulated glutamine synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase leads to argininosuccinic aciduria

Option C: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A leads to Fabry’s disease and an accumulation of globotriaosylceramide.

Option D: Deficiency of arginase leads to hyperargininemia

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine
questions.solution:
Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: Excess ammonia reduces which of the following substrates of the Krebs cycle?
questions.solution:
Excess ammonia results in depletion of levels of alpha-ketoglutarate.

This happens because excess ammonia reacts with alpha-ketoglutarate to form glutamate, mainly in the CNS.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels, whose conductance is reduced in proportion to the degree of hypoxia.

This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux.

The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings.

questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome or Zellweger's syndrome is characterized by the accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acid, abnormalities of synthesis of bile acids and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

It occurs in individuals with a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes. It is due to mutations in genes encoding certain proteins called peroxins (involved in various steps of peroxisome biogenesis) in all tissues. They accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life.

Because of the poor outcome and high disease burden associated with Zellweger's syndorme, genetic counselling should be offered to parents of affected children. Carriers can be offered prenatal or preimplantation genetic diagnosis. Treatment is often supportive and symptom-based.

This question was asked in the recent AIIMS examination, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: In a patient with lipoprotein lipase deficiency, which of the following is increased following a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
After a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols). This is called a nascent chylomicron, which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL is remodelled into mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyzes the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food.

Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

Note: In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of the esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge reflex.

Atrial Reflex Control of Heart Rate: The Bainbridge Reflex

  • The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain.
  • Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Bezold-Jarisch Reflex:

  • Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Cushing Reflex:

  • When ICP is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised.
  • The local hypoxia and hypercapnia causes an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia and irregular respiration.
  • The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) maintains the patency of ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is used in term neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention as they have duct-dependant circulation.

Indomethacin and Ibuprofen are the NSAID indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in premature infants and neonates.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin?

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.solution: Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except ______

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the ɣ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.solution:
In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body).

Decerebration

  • Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration.
  • This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities.
  • The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact.
  • The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called decerebrate rigidity.
  • The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates γ-motor neurons which indirectly activate α-motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop.

Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding De Quervain’s tenosynovitis?

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.solution:
De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL).

It is prominent among females, especially pregnant women. Most commonly thumb is involved.

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient’s thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It’s the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

Treatment:

  • Majority of the patients are treated medically
  • Only few require the release of the 1st dorsal compartment which houses the APL and EPB tendons.

questions.text: The arrow in the image denotes which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The arrow shows extensor carpi radialis longus.

It originates from the distal third of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts at the second metacarpal (radial side). It is innervated by the radial nerve, C6, and C7.

The vascular supply is by radial recurrent artery and it is responsible for the extension and abduction of the wrist joint.

questions.text: Nerve supply of the area marked by arrow in the image is:
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is mandibular foramen and inferior alveolar nerve passes through it.

The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN), a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), it descends behind the lateral pterygoid, at the lower border of the muscle, the nerve passes between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen

The mandibular foramen is located above the mandibular angle, the opening through which the IAN and the vessels of the mandible pass.
The IAN continues its course through the mandibular canal and then branches off to supply the lower teeth, gums, and lower lip.

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal capsule, which is a form of projection fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
The gall bladder does not form a boundary of the Calot’s triangle.

Calot's triangle is bounded by 3C's:

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery 

 

Clinical Note: Proper exposure of Calot's triangle and careful identification of the anatomic structures are keys to avoiding common bile duct injuries. This is the most common site of injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Medially

Inferiorly

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?
questions.solution:
Based on the agglutination test shown in the image, the blood group is O positive.

As agglutination is present only in 'Rh' and not with 'A' and 'B' hence the blood group is O Rh positive.

questions.text: What is the function of tubuloglomerular feedback?
questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

As the rate of ﬂow through the ascending limb of the loop of Henle and first part of the distal tubule increases, glomerular filtration in the same nephron decreases, and, conversely, a decrease in ﬂow increases the GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following neurons predominantly fire during forceful expiration?
questions.solution:
Ventral groups of neurons fire, when forceful expiration is needed like during heavy exercise.

Dorsal group of neurons control the normal inspiration and expiration.

Pneumotaxic center limits the duration of inspiration.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

Respiratory center component

Primary function

Pre-Bőtzinger complex

Pacemaker cells of spontaneous or automatic breathing

Dorsal Respiratory Group (DRG)

Respiratory rhythm generator (inspiratory ramp signal)

Ventral Respiratory Group (VRG)

Overdrive mechanism

Pneumotaxic centre

Controls the “switch off” point of inspiratory ramp signal

Apneustic centre

Delays switch off signal- promotes inspiration

Vagi

Inhibits inspiratory discharge

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?
questions.solution:
The antidiuretic hormone acts through aquaporin channel 2.

ADH binds to V2 receptors in the late distal tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts, and stimulates the movement of an intracellular protein, called aquaporin-2 (AQP-2), to the luminal side of the cell membranes.

Clinical note: Lithium, which is often used to treat bipolar disorder, can cause acquired diabetes insipidus by decreasing the expression of the AQP2 gene. 

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Osmosis, AQ 1

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

No water reabsorption

questions.text: The X-ray of a 65-year-old man is given below. Clinical examination, and hematological and urinary tests were normal. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim with a beveled edge appearance, along with the age of the patient with history of normal hematological and urinary tests is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens.

It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions. It can also infiltrate the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulosae.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include epilepsy, features of raised intracranial tension, and evident hydrocephalus. Patients can also have psychiatric disturbances, transient paresis, and visual disturbances. 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

  • Scolex within a cyst
  • Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • Nodular calcifications
  • Focal enhancing lesions
  • Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (an antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

questions.text: A 30 year old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same.

choices.text: The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool is given below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain - positive oocysts as seen in the given image is suggestive of Cryptosporidium.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round,  contains four sporozites which is uniformly acid fast on staining.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contain two sporocyst, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid fast Variable acid fast Uniformly acid fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. He complains of retrosternal chest pain that is worse on inspiration. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a case of pneumonia in a HIV positive patient, along with the presence of fever, and non-productive cough with radiographic findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrates and symmetric perihilar involvement is Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP). A characteristic feature of PCP is retrosternal chest pain, which worsens on inspiration and is described as sharp or burning.

It is important to note that even though the incidence of PCP is the highest at CD4+ counts of <200/μL (80%), it can be seen in patients with higher counts.

Other options:

Option D: Tuberculosis (TB) should be considered as a possibility in cases of pneumonia in people living with HIV. However, the absence of hilar lymph node involvement, non-productive cough, and no extrapulmonary (pleural, pericardial, lymphatic) features are not consistent with tuberculosis.

TB can occur at any stage of HIV infection. In the early stages, pulmonary TB appears typically with upper-lobe infiltrates and cavitation. In advanced HIV infection, with CD4+ T-cell count below 200/μL, TB presents with diffuse interstitial infiltrates, minimal cavitation, pleural effusion, and lymphadenopathy. Extrapulmonary TB is fairly common in HIV, with it being documented in 40-60% of cases.

Option A: Staphylococcal pneumonia most commonly presents with a productive cough, and radiologically presents with pneumatoceles (cavitations)

Option B: Patients with pneumococcal pneumonia also present with fever, dyspnea, and productive cough. Imaging usually shows lobar involvement.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.solution:
Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C).

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis.

Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis. That is conditions with a long lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the population change over years from 1983 to 1989 in a given place. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a component bar graph. It is used to represent data in which the total magnitude is divided into different subsets or components.

A bar chart or bar graph is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data. They can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

The image given below shows a multiple bar graph showing the human losses of world war II by country. In a multiple bar chart, 2 or more sets of data are shown simultaneously.  

A bar chart can be distinguished from a histogram because the rectangles are separated by the spaces. This indicates that the data forms discrete categories.

In a histogram, the rectangles are not separated by spaces as the data represented forms a continuous set instead of discrete groups.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A patient died from bronchopneumonia following an intracerebral hemorrhage caused by cerebral metastases from a squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus. What should be recorded in the line I (c) of the death certificate?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
Cerebral metastasis will be filled in the line I (c) of the death certificate, as one of the antecedent causes in the order of the events that took place. 

The death certificate will be filled in the order of the events that took place, as follows:

This MCQ has been revised, as per the recommendations of Forty-Third World Health Assembly 1990, in which an additional line (d) was added below (c) in part I of the death certificate, as approved by the WHO. Part II will only be filled up with a a significant condition contributing to the death but not related to the disease or condition causing it.

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
History and physical examination findings are suggestive of meningitis.

The given image shows intracellular gram negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

Option a:Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

Option c: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

Option d: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus.

questions.text: Rigor mortis occurs first in:
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis occurs first in the myocardium.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Left chamber of heart is affected first. Other muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Note- Rigor mortis first occurs in the myocardium but is first seen in eyelids. Here the question is first occurs in and the answer is myocardium.

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC/BNS deals with the punishment of perjury?
questions.solution:
The punishment of perjury is dealt with under IPC 193, has now been updated to BNS 229. 

Perjury is defined as the offence of wilfully telling an untruth or making a misrepresentation under oath.

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury, there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound. The injury is:
questions.solution:
Based on the ballistics, the gunshot injury is close shot entry wound.

  • The main objective of study of a firearm wound (Ballistics) is to establish the range and direction of firing, the ultimate purpose is to determine the weapon used for firing.
  • Firearm wounds are fundamentally of two mains types: wounds of entry and wound of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.
  • To determine the Range of firing, following parameters are used:
    • Entry wound size and shape
    • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
    • Blackening, Tattooing, Singeing of hair, Abrasion collar and Grease collar
  • In the above options, Hair should be preserved in order to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonisation/dessication in close range, also from lead deposition around the wound to assess range of firing.

questions.text: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her actually having the disease?
questions.solution:
Positive predictive value implies the probability of a person with a positive test, actually having the disease.

It is the ability of a test to detect true positive(TP) out of total positive(TP+FP) and it is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

PPV= TP/TP+FP

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: The test of significance done for two or more proportions:
questions.solution:
Chi-Square(χ2) test is a test used for proportions and associations.

It is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is:
questions.solution:
The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is unpaired T test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000.

It is also known as a sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method, waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then, it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits

questions.text: Cross product ratio can be arrived from:
questions.solution:
Cross product ratio (Odds ratio) can be obtained from the case-control study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: The principal unit of administration in India is ______
questions.solution:
• The principal unit of administration in India is the district under a Collector.
  • Under districts are the sub-divisions, tahsils or talukas, municipalities or corporations, villages, panchayats, etc.
  • As of the 2019 census, there are 725 districts in India.

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
questions.solution: Levofloxacin and ofloxacin have the maximum bioavailability among fluoroquinolones.  Hence, intravenous and oral doses are the same for these drugs.

questions.text: Triage is done during disaster management to ensure treatment of casualties is done properly. What is true about triage done at the disaster site?

choices.text: Green labels are for those who need to be transported on priority
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority
Most commonly used system is three  color code system

questions.solution:
Moribund patients receive the lowest priority. 

This is because despite paying quite a lot of attention, the benefit is still questionable.

 

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Triazoles act by inhibition of ergosterol synthesis.

The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

Azole antifungals are of two types:

  • Imidazoles - clotrimazole, ketoconazole, luliconazole
  • Triazoles - itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole and isavuconazole

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
questions.solution:
Mucicarmine stain is used in the identification of cryptococcus.

Mucicarmine stain helps in the detection of the cryptococcal capsule, as it stains mucins of epithelial origin (PAS, alcian blue). Given below is an image of Mucicarmine stained specimen of lung tissue containing cryptococci:

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons).  The basic cycles of transmission are:

 (a)Pig → Mosquito  → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy?
questions.solution:
A saturated salt solution is used commonly for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy.

Rectified spirit is indicated for most of the poisons, exceptions being alcohol, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, carbolic acid, acetic acid, etc.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by:
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning.

In carbolic acid poisoning, if the patient survives for 48 hrs, there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

It is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

  • Corrosives poisoning (except carbolic acid)
  • Convulsants/CNS stimulants
  • Comatose patients
  • Volatile poison
  • Upper GI pathology (eg. esophageal varices)
  • Hypothermic patient
  • Severe heart disease
  • Advanced pregnancy

Sulphuric acid and kerosene are corrosives and strychnine is a convulsant. Hence gastric lavage is not done in these poisonings.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of corrosives

Corrosive Mechanism of Action Type of necrosis
Strong acids Hydrogen ions penetrate tissues and lead to cell death and eschar formation. This prevents further hydrogen ion penetration and protects against deeper injury. Coagulation necrosis
Carbolic acid Same as other strong acids, but also hardens the GI mucosa. Produces a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. Coagulation necrosis 
Oxalic acid Same as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis
Hydrofluoric acid Fluoride ions scavenge intracellular cations, such as calcium and magnesium and inhibit Na/K ATPase, disrupting cell membranes. This leads to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. Liquefactive necrosis
Strong alkalis Hydroxide ions easily penetrate tissues, leading to the dissolution of cell membranes. It is associated with deep tissue injury. Liquefactive necrosis

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Immune reactions involving blood vessels, as seen in the case of polyarteritis nodosa, usually show fibrinoid necrosis. Fibrinoid means fibrin-like.

In some immune disorders, the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessels. These complexes result in complement activation (type III hypersensitivity) leading to cell injury. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around the blood vessels.

Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:

  • SLE
  • Libman-sacks endocarditis
  • Arthus reaction
  • Serum sickness
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Malignant hypertension

questions.text: What is the best way to plot the changes in incidence of a disease in a given area over time?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.

The image below shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani.

questions.text: The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is?
questions.solution:
The risk of genetic diseases in consanguineous marriage between first cousins is 4-8%.

The risk of genetic diseases in non-consanguineous marriage is 2-4%.

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug?

choices.text: It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight
Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 6 months after therapy
Acitretin has a half life of about 50 hours

questions.solution:
Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after discontinuing acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid-induced embryopathy.

Acitretin is approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.

Absolute contraindications:

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breastfeeding

Relative contraindications:

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

Note: Female patients should avoid conception for 1 month after discontinuation of isotretinoin.

questions.text: A paradoxical carrier is defined as:

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.solution:
A paradoxical carrier is a carrier that acquired a pathogen from another carrier.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. 

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. 

Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: All are true about Barrett oesophagus except:

choices.text: Seen in 10% of  individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
Barrett's esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.

Barrett's esophagus is a complication of GERD and it is estimated to occur in as many as 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia). 

The following images show endoscopic and microscopic images of Barrett's esophagus:

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by:
questions.solution:
Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.

HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted:

  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Ground-glass changes in nuclei
  • Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.

The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.

The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.

The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.

questions.text: De-gloving injury refers to ______

choices.text: Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia are stripped from tendons
Skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and tendons are stripped from bone

questions.solution:
Degloving is the avulsion of skin and subcutaneous fat from the underlying fascia, muscle or bone.

Degloving injuries can be open or closed. An example of open degloving injury is finger avulsion injury with loss of skin. Closed degloving injuries result from shearing forces (e.g. motor vehicle collisions).

The extent of degloving injuries are often underappreciated and much of the skin may be non-viable.  Disruption of perforating vascular and lymphatic vessels may result in a characteristic haemolymphatic collection between the fascial planes called a Morel-Lavallée lesion. 

Patterns of degloving injury:

  1. Limited degloving with abrasion or avulsion
  2. Non-circumferential degloving
  3. Circumferential single plane degloving
  4. Circumferential multiplanar degloving 

Assessing the viability of degloved tissue can be difficult and may therefore require more than one surgical exploration and debridement before definitive reconstruction. Non-viable skin may show fixed staining and thrombosis of subcutaneous veins. Most surgeons serially excise the degloved skin until punctate dermal bleeding is seen from viable tissue. 

Intravenous fluorescein can help in delineating non-viable tissue, but it requires specialist equipment and there is a small risk of anaphylaxis. Indocyanine green has been found to have less risk of allergy. 

Open degloving injuries are managed by reattaching the viable skin and grafting. Closed degloving injuries are managed by draining the accumulated fluid, removing the dead tissue and sclerotherapy. For severe, multiplanar degloving, amputation is done. 

The given image below shows a degloving injury of the lower limb:

questions.solution:
